The cooled gas and the liquid that flashes in the Suction Chiller are then compressed to approximately 75 PSIG. A portion of the compressed gas (up to 100 tons/day) is diverted to make sodium hypochlorite bleach by direct contact with a solution of sodium hydroxide. During operations, one tank is normally empty and the other is maintained with some inventory (200 tons or less).
Liquid collected in the Low Grade Chlorine Storage Tanks is vaporized and used to supplement the chlorine flow to the sodium hypochlorite bleach plant. Liquid in the High Grade Chlorine Storage Tanks is vaporized and used to supply Dow with chlorine via pipeline. Incident Investigation
All incidents, no matter how minor, whether personal injury or chemical release, shall be reported immediately to the immediate supervisor for investigation and evaluation. Since every accident includes a sequence of contributing causes, it may be possible to avoid a repeat performance of the first event by recognizing and eliminating these causes. The removal of a single cause may prevent a recurrence.
The incident must be investigated using a technique appropriate to the severity of theincident. In most cases, Root Cause Analysis is the appropriate investigation technique.However, in severe or complex incidents, other approaches may be considered.
After completion of the investigation, the final report shall be submitted to the Safety Committee for review. The Safety Committee may recommend additional actions, beyond the report recommendations. All department managers and Team Leaders shall review the minutes, including the PIA report with all team members. All recommended corrective actions shall be captured on the master plant Corrective Action Review summary and tracked to resolution. 
Minor Injuries, Illnesses and Releases
After completing the emergency actions following an accident, an investigation of the accident will be conducted by the immediate supervisor in conjunction with any witnesses to determine the possible causes. The Safety Committee shall appoint an investigation team to conduct a Root Cause Analysis or other investigation Injuries must be documented on the Supervisors Accident Investigation Report

Corporate philosophy requires that facilities continuously identify methods to reduce the use of hazardous materials and to reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of inherently safer technology and procedures. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in K2 Pure's EH&S Policy which reads:
Protection of safety, health, environment and community is our overriding priority. All adverse incidents can and must be prevented.
 K2 Pure Solutions stresses safe and environmentally sound operations in employee training programs, and in written materials available at the Plant.  K2 Pure Solutions safety and environmental programs include monthly safety meeting of all employees and a joint worker/company Safety Committee. It is K2 Pure's philosophy to pursue continuous improvement in all aspects of plant operation. The purpose of this standard is to define the procedure and authority levels for making plant changes in the implementation of continuous improvement in a manner that allows for team input. This will assure plant safety, environmental responsibility, product quality, and efficient plant operation.
K2 Pure's MOC process applies to any changes made to the Pittsburg plant production processes.  This includes any change to process chemicals, technology, equipment, or process safety information (PSI) used in the plant production processes. It includes such things as changes in materials of construction, physical s or capacities, raw materials, operating procedures, process parameters, control schemes, equipment additions, deletions, or rearrangements, and changes to the organization chart and staffing levels. Plant changes do not include routine maintenance of equipment.  Plant changes also typically do not include replacements in kind. However, any replacement or change that does not comply with current engineering standards shall be considered a plant change.

Any employee may initiate a Management of Change (MOC) by completing a Design Change Request (DCR) form. The Description field should be used to communicate the technical basis for the change.
